items.title: These maps explain the battle for the Arctic and Trump's 'own goal'
items.description: After a week of escalating rhetoric over Greenland, Donald Trump says he has now secured "total access" to the Arctic island. This is why that region is so important.

items.title: TikTok finalises deal to form new American version of app
items.description: Social media giant TikTok reaches a deal for a new joint venture in the United States to avoid being banned for American users. The platform's Beijing-based parent company, ByteDance, will retain a 19.9 per cent stake in the company.

items.title: Paris Hilton brings sex tape story to Washington for AI porn fight
items.description: The party girl turned anti-abuse advocate throws her glamorous celebrity heft behind a push to tackle deepfake pornography.

items.title: Scientists revive 3.2-billion-year-old enzyme to study early life on Earth

featured_image.name: Resurrected ancient enzyme offers new window into early ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of Wisconsin–Madison have resurrected a 3.2-billion-year-old enzyme and studied it inside living microbes, creating a new way to understand the origins of life on Earth and potentially recognize signs of life on other planets.

The NASA-funded study, published in Nature Communications on January 22, uses synthetic biology to reverse-engineer modern enzymes and rebuild their ancient ancestors. The research team, led by Betül Kaçar, a professor of bacteriology, and Holly Rucker, a PhD candidate in Kaçar's lab, focused on nitrogenase, an enzyme essential for converting atmospheric nitrogen into a form usable by living organisms.[1][2]

"We picked an enzyme that really set the tone of life on this planet and then interrogated its history," Kaçar says. "Without nitrogenase, there would be no life as we know it."[3][1]

items.title: Greenland Ice Sheet could vanish by 2300 under high emissions, study finds

featured_image.name: Greenland's inland ice is melting far faster than anyone thought

items.description: New research has revealed that under high-emission scenarios, the Greenland Ice Sheet could largely disappear over the coming centuries, threatening to raise global sea levels by more than seven meters and reshape coastlines worldwide. Scientists warn that accelerating ice loss and newly identified feedback mechanisms may be pushing Greenland's ice toward a point of no return.

items.title: British Australians confused, frustrated by new UK entry rules
items.description: Confused dual citizens are voicing their frustrations as they grapple with changes to the UK's entry requirements, which roll out next month.

items.title: Trump, Zelenskyy hold talks in Davos as peace deal nears

featured_image.name: Trump and Zelensky hold talks in Davos

items.description:
President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met for approximately one hour behind closed doors at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday, with both leaders describing the discussions as productive amid signs of progress toward a potential end to the nearly four-year war with Russia.

Trump told reporters the meeting was "good" and reiterated his message: "The war has to end." Zelenskyy described the talks as "productive and meaningful," thanking Trump for his efforts to "stop the bloodshed and bring the war to an end."[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Live: Aussie wildcards dump out top seeds as Osaka urged to 'say less'
items.description: A pair of tennis greats suggest Naomi Osaka may want to quiet down on court after her clash with Sorana Cirstea, while Australian wildcard pair James McCabe and Li Tu beat the men's doubles top seeds on day six of the Australian Open. Follow live.

items.title: Study finds climate adaptation can curb migration in Africa

featured_image.name: Drought-tolerant hybrid seed offers farmers reprieve from ...

items.description:
Investments that help communities withstand drought and conflict—especially by boosting farm productivity and basic services—may also curb displacement pressures across Africa, according to a new peer‑reviewed study published in the journal Sustainable Development.[1][2]

The research, led by Hyun Kim of Chungnam National University, analyzes African country- and grid-level data spanning 1995–2015 and finds that **stronger “adaptive capacity”** is associated with **lower migration during periods of drought or armed conflict**, acting as a buffer when shocks hit.[3][2][1]

items.title: EU Parliament freezes U.S. trade deal over Trump tariffs

featured_image.name: E.U. halts approval of U.S. trade deal after Trump's Greenland tariff ...

items.description:
European lawmakers have frozen work on an EU-U.S. trade agreement after President Donald Trump tied threatened tariffs on key U.S. allies to his push for greater U.S. control and access in Greenland, reopening a geopolitical dispute that had already rattled markets this week.[1][2][3]

The standoff escalated after Trump said he would impose new duties on eight European countries beginning Feb. 1 unless an arrangement was reached over Greenland—then reversed course in Davos, saying he would not use force and that a “framework” with NATO was in view, prompting a relief bounce in equities.[4][5][6][7]

items.title: Putin meets US envoys in Kremlin as Ukraine talks near final stretch

featured_image.name: Putin meets US envoys for late-night talks on Ukraine | Reuters

items.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin began late-night talks with US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner at the Kremlin on Thursday, January 22, 2026, as diplomatic efforts to end the nearly four-year Ukraine war enter what negotiators describe as a final stretch.

The meeting, which started shortly before midnight Moscow time, brought together three American representatives—Witkoff, Kushner, and newly appointed senior adviser Josh Gruenbaum—with Putin's team, including foreign policy aide Yuri Ushakov and special envoy Kirill Dmitriev, according to the Kremlin's official account. A brief video released by Russian state media showed Putin shaking hands with the American delegation and inviting them to a long oval table.[1][2][3]

items.title: Defiant Sussan Ley downplays Nationals' exit, vows to remain leader
items.description: The Liberal leader did not speak about the Nationals' decision to terminate the Coalition on yesterday's National Day of Mourning, but on Friday insisted her focus was on the government.

items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS reaches rare opposition today

featured_image.name: New images capture rare interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS passing ...

items.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS reaches a rare and fleeting celestial alignment today, positioning itself directly opposite the sun from Earth's perspective and offering scientists a once-in-decades opportunity to study material from another star system before the enigmatic visitor departs forever.

At 13:00 UTC on January 22, 2026, 3I/ATLAS will align to within just 0.69 degrees of the Earth-Sun axis—an exceptionally small angle that creates ideal conditions for what astronomers call an "opposition surge," a phenomenon that will cause the object to appear brighter and reveal more about its composition. Unlike typical cometary oppositions that last only hours, this alignment will keep 3I/ATLAS within two degrees of the axis for approximately one week.[1][2][3]

items.title: Webb telescope solves mystery of how crystals form in icy comets

featured_image.name: Webb telescope captures 'breathtaking' images of Orion Nebula

items.description:
The James Webb Space Telescope has delivered a striking one-two punch of cosmic discoveries this week, capturing the clearest infrared images ever taken of the Helix Nebula while also solving a decades-old puzzle about how crystals found in comets formed in the frozen reaches of space.

NASA unveiled the new Helix Nebula images on Tuesday, offering an unprecedented look at one of the most photographed planetary nebulas in the sky. Located 650 light-years from Earth in the constellation Aquarius and often called the "Eye of God," the nebula has never appeared with such detail.[1][2][3]

items.title: Shell weighs sale of Argentina shale assets, sources say

featured_image.name: Vaca Muerta shale formation propels Argentina closer to ...

items.description:
Shell is considering selling some or all of its assets in Argentina's Vaca Muerta shale formation, a move that would mark a surprise exit by one of the region's earliest backers just as international interest in the massive play intensifies, according to a Reuters report citing three sources familiar with the matter.[1][2]

The oil major has approached potential buyers in recent weeks to gauge interest in the holdings, which are likely to be valued in the billions of dollars, two of the sources said. However, a sale is not guaranteed, and Shell could still choose to retain the assets. The company declined to comment.[2][3][1]

items.title: Live: Albanese predicts 'at least one more' Coalition MP will defect to One Nation
items.description: The PM's comments came after Nationals leader David Littleproud said he was open to working with Liberal leader Sussan Ley again "at some point", but right now the two parties need "a bit of time apart". Follow live.

items.title: Live: Pregnant woman among three dead in domestic violence shooting
items.description: Tactical police join a growing air and land search for a man police have identified after three people, including a pregnant woman, were shot dead in a remote New South Wales town.

items.title: 'Hug your babies': Search continues for people buried under NZ landslide
items.description: Specialist officers have worked through the night with earthmoving equipment to try and find those trapped under the rubble at a popular tourist spot on New Zealand's North Island.

items.title: Trump and China offer dueling visions on trade at Davos

featured_image.name: New trade map takes shape in Davos as world adjusts to Trump tariffs

items.description:
The 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, became a stage for clashing economic worldviews this week as President Donald Trump defended his aggressive tariff policies while Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng championed multilateralism and free trade—a split that is accelerating the reshaping of global economic alliances.

Trump addressed the forum on Wednesday, touting what he called an "economic miracle" achieved through tariffs that he said slashed the U.S. monthly trade deficit by 77 percent in one year. "Virtually all of the so-called experts predicted my plans to end this failed model would trigger a global recession and runaway inflation. But we have proven them wrong," he declared. He criticized European economic policies, stating that "certain places in Europe are not even recognizable, frankly, anymore."[1]

items.title: One Nation's rise in popularity changes the context of the Coalition's divorce
items.description: It is impossible to view this week’s events without the broader context of the relationship between the Liberals and the Nationals, how the electoral map is changing and what that means for right-wing politics in Australia.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
